Q1: What is the name of the serial film depicted in the passage?
A1: The Eagle's Eye

Q2: Who directed and produced the serial?
A2: George Lessey, Wellington A. Playter, Leopold Wharton, and Theodore Wharton

Q3: What is the name of the magazine where the episodes were published?
A3: The Atlanta Constitution's magazine section

Q4: Who played the lead roles in the serial?
A4: King Baggot as Harrison Grant, Marguerite Snow as Dixie Mason, William Bailey as Heinrich von Lertz, Florence Short as Madame Augusta Stephan, Bertram Marburgh as Count Johann von Bernstorff, Paul Everton as Captain Franz von Papen, John P. Wade as Captain Karl Boy-Ed, Fred C. Jones as Dr. Heinrich Albert, Wellington A. Playter as Franz von Rintelen, and Bessie Wharton as Mrs. Blank

Q5: How many episodes were there in the serial?
A5: 20 episodes

Q6: What was the title of the book that reprinted 15 of the episodes?
A6: The Eagle's Eye: A True Story of the Imperial German Government's Spies and Intrigues in America

Q7: Who were some of the notable characters in the serial?
A7: King Baggot as Harrison Grant, Marguerite Snow as Dixie Mason, William Bailey as Heinrich von Lertz, Florence Short as Madame Augusta Stephan, Bertram Marburgh as Count Johann von Bernstorff, Paul Everton as Captain Franz von Papen, John P. Wade as Captain Karl Boy-Ed, Fred C. Jones as Dr. Heinrich Albert, Wellington A. Playter as Franz von Rintelen

Q8: What were some of the events depicted in the serial?
A8: Sending of the Zimmermann Telegram, attempts to sabotage cargo loading in San Francisco Harbor, and the capture of the German espionage plans.

Q9: Why was the serial a commercial failure?
A9: The studio was forced to declare bankruptcy due to the serial's commercial failure.

Q10: How many episodes were there in the original publication?
A10: 20 episodes

Q11: What was the name of the magazine where the episodes were originally published?
A11: The Atlanta Constitution's magazine section

Q12: Who wrote the stories depicted in the serial?
A12: Courtney Ryley Cooper interwoven fictitious characters and events from Flynn's work investigating sabotage during World War I.

Q13: What was the name of the president of the Criminology Club in the serial?
A13: King Baggot as Harrison Grant

Q14: Who played the role of a Secret Service agent in the serial?
A14: Marguerite Snow as Dixie Mason

Q15: What was the name of the book that reprinted 15 of the episodes?
A15: The Eagle's Eye: A True Story of the Imperial German Government's Spies and Intrigues in America.

Q1: Who is the executive director of the Sam Spiegel Film and Television School?
A1: Dana Blankstein-Cohen.

Q2: When was Dana Blankstein appointed as the executive director of the Sam Spiegel Film and Television School?
A2: In November 2019.

Q3: What is Dana Blankstein's profession?
A3: She is a film director and an Israeli culture entrepreneur.

Q4: Where was Dana Blankstein born?
A4: Switzerland.

Q5: When did Dana Blankstein move to Israel?
A5: In 1983.

Q6: What is Dana Blankstein's educational background?
A6: She graduated from the Sam Spiegel Film and Television School in 2008 with high honors.

Q7: What are some of Dana Blankstein's notable works?
A7: She directed the mini-series "Tel Aviviot" (2012) and the graduation film "Growing Pains" (2008), and her debut film "Camping" (2006) competed at the Berlin International Film Festival.

Q8: What is Dana Blankstein's current position?
A8: She is the executive director of the Sam Spiegel Film and Television School, where she also oversees the Sam Spiegel International Film Lab.

Q9: What new initiative did Dana Blankstein spearhead in 2022?
A9: She launched the new Series Lab and the film preparatory program for Arabic speakers in east Jerusalem.

Q10: How many films has Dana Blankstein directed?
A10: Three (Tel Aviviot, Growing Pains, and Camping).

Q1: What is the title of the film being discussed in the passage?

A2: Philippines

A3: Carl Franklin

A4: 1989

A5: Eric Reifschneider gave the film a rating of 2.5/5.

Q6: What does the reviewer from actionfreunde.de say about the director's approach to the war?
A6: Nils Bothmann writes that director Carl Franklin "illustrates the American disappointment in this unheroic war."

Q7: How did a reviewer from outlawvern.com describe the film?
A7: Vern writes, "this is an example of the kind of thing I like where a director is able to put their stamp on lowbrow genre movies and later evolve into whatever it is they want to do."

Q8: What does the reviewer from mondo-esoterica.com say about the film's action scenes?
A8: Timothy Young writes, "the action scenes feel flat - fortunately this is not an action picture and the rest of the film looks good with some strong acting."

Q9: What is the focus of the film according to the passage?
A9: The film's focus is on characters, not low-budget action antics.

Q10: How did the film perform at the box office?
A10: No information is provided in the passage.
